Anti-trans bills in Tennessee have created a mental health crisis | Opinion@tennessean7/8/2022

Anti-trans bills send a clear, harmful message to trans youth that they are not welcome in society, furthering feelings of isolation and rejection.

data-c-credit="Nashville Tennessean"></div></aside><ul class=gnt_ar_sh><li class=gnt_ar_sh_li>Dr. Britta Roach is a pediatrician, and currently a pediatric emergency medicine fellow at Monroe Carell Jr. Children’s Hospital at Vanderbilt in Nashville, TN.</li></ul><p class=gnt_ar_b_p>As I stepped into the patient’s room, I saw a teenager sitting on the hospital bed. I introduced myself as the physician and asked, “What is your preferred name?” The patient responded with a name different than the one in the medical record and preemptively shared his preferred pronouns: he, him, and his.</p><p class=gnt_ar_b_p>As we began talking, he disclosed that he had attempted suicide at home. His mother interrupted, “I found empty pill bottles in her bedroom.” As is typical of all psychiatric assessments, I asked the mother to leave the room so that I could speak to the patient alone.</p><p class=gnt_ar_b_p>He opened up more about his transgender identity — sharing that he had attempted suicide due to his unsupportive family and bullying at school. Unfortunately, as a pediatric ED physician, this is a common patient encounter for two reasons.</p><p class=gnt_ar_b_p>Suicide is the <a href=https://wisqars.cdc.gov/cgi-bin/broker.exe target=_blank rel=noopener data-t-l=":b|e|inline click|${u}" class=gnt_ar_b_a>second leading cause of death</a> among youth, and second, <a href="https://www.thetrevorproject.org/survey-2021/?section=Introduction" target=_blank rel=noopener data-t-l=":b|e|inline click|${u}" class=gnt_ar_b_a>more than half of transgender youth</a> considered suicide in 2021. Despite this disheartening data, legislators across the United States continue to introduce<a href=/story/opinion/2022/03/03/tennessee-seeks-cause-harm-adding-more-anti-lgbtq-legislation/9350521002/ target=_blank rel=noopener data-t-l=":b|e|inline click|${u}" class=gnt_ar_b_a> anti-trans bills</a>.</p><p class=gnt_ar_b_p><strong>Hear more Tennessee Voices:</strong> <a href=https://profile.tennessean.com/newsletters/Tennessee-Voices/ target=_blank rel=noopener data-t-l=":b|e|inline click|${u}" class=gnt_ar_b_a>Get the weekly opinion newsletter for insightful and thought provoking columns.</a></p><h2 class=gnt_ar_b_h2>States across the country are introducing harmful laws</h2><figure class="gnt_em gnt_em_img"><img class=gnt_em_img_i style=height:440px data-g-r=lazy data-gl-src="https://www.gannett-cdn.com/presto/2021/05/21/PNAS/b549c8d6-3f82-41c2-871a-b3984c6bdcfe-IMG_7680.JPG?width=660&height=440&fit=crop&format=pjpg&auto=webp" data-gl-srcset="https://www.gannett-cdn.com/presto/2021/05/21/PNAS/b549c8d6-3f82-41c2-871a-b3984c6bdcfe-IMG_7680.JPG?width=1320&height=880&fit=crop&format=pjpg&auto=webp 2x" decoding=async alt="Parents of transgender children and LGBTQ rights advocates gathered at the First Lutheran Church to protest Tennessee's slate of anti-LGBTQ bills signed into law in 2021."/><div class="gnt_em_img_ccw gnt_em_img_ccw__cap gnt_em_img_ccw__crd" data-c-caption="Parents of transgender children and LGBTQ rights advocates gathered at the First Lutheran Church to protest Tennessee's slate of anti-LGBTQ bills signed into law in 2021." data-c-credit="Yue Stella Yu, Nashville Tennessean"></div></figure><p class=gnt_ar_b_p><a href=https://gov.texas.gov/uploads/files/press/O-MastersJaime202202221358.pdf target=_blank rel=noopener data-t-l=":b|e|inline click|${u}" class=gnt_ar_b_a>Texas introduced</a> a directive that would re-classify medical treatment for trans youth as child abuse. The Florida Senate passed the <a href=https://www.flsenate.gov/Session/Bill/2022/1557/BillText/e1/PDF target=_blank rel=noopener data-t-l=":b|e|inline click|${u}" class=gnt_ar_b_a>“Don’t Say Gay” bill</a> which bans classroom discussion about gender identity.</p><p class=gnt_ar_b_p>The <a href=/story/opinion/2022/03/01/lgbtq-tennessee-lawmakers-continue-their-attack-trans-youths/9330501002/ target=_blank rel=noopener data-t-l=":b|e|inline click|${u}" class=gnt_ar_b_a>Tennessee Senate</a> has proposed the <a href=https://www.capitol.tn.gov/Bills/112/Bill/SB2696.pdf target=_blank rel=noopener data-t-l=":b|e|inline click|${u}" class=gnt_ar_b_a>“Youth Health Protection Act,”</a> which would prohibit and criminalize gender affirming medications and surgeries for transgender youth. </p><p class=gnt_ar_b_p>The <a href=https://www.aap.org/ target=_blank rel=noopener data-t-l=":b|e|inline click|${u}" class=gnt_ar_b_a>American Academy of Pediatrics</a> (AAP), a professional association of pediatricians, has firmly supported transgender medicine. A <a href=https://publications.aap.org/pediatrics/article/142/4/e20182162/37381/Ensuring-Comprehensive-Care-and-Support-for target=_blank rel=noopener data-t-l=":b|e|inline click|${u}" class=gnt_ar_b_a>policy statement released</a> in 2018, outlining the Gender-Affirmative Care Model whereby “pediatric providers [should] offer developmentally appropriate care that is oriented toward understanding and appreciating the youth’s gender experience.”</p><aside aria-label=advertisement class="gnt_m gnt_x gnt_x__lbl gnt_x__al"><div data-g-r=lazy data-gl-method=lazyLoadX id=~ad-slot-7103-tn-nashville-C1056-native-article_link-news-opinion-2 class="gnt_x_sl gnt_x_al"></div></aside><p class=gnt_ar_b_p><strong>Hear from Tennessee's Black Voices:</strong> <a href=https://profile.tennessean.com/newsletters/Black-Tennessee-Voices/ target=_blank rel=noopener data-t-l=":b|e|inline click|${u}" class=gnt_ar_b_a>Get the weekly newsletter for powerful and critical thinking columns.</a></p><h2 class=gnt_ar_b_h2>Anti-trans bills negatively affect trans youth's mental health</h2><p class=gnt_ar_b_p>This month, the Tennessee AAP chapter organized its annual "Day on the Hill," allowing pediatricians to advocate to legislators on behalf of children state-wide. After spending the day expressing our staunch opposition to the “Youth Health Protection Act,” my fellow pediatricians and I learned that this bill would likely not pass.</p><figure class="gnt_em gnt_em_img gnt_em_img__inset"><img class=gnt_em_img_i style=height:420px data-g-r=lazy data-gl-src="https://www.gannett-cdn.com/presto/2022/03/15/PNAS/ef515705-9770-4754-86bd-22ad65831b62-Britta_Roach.JPG?width=300&height=420&fit=crop&format=pjpg&auto=webp" data-gl-srcset="https://www.gannett-cdn.com/presto/2022/03/15/PNAS/ef515705-9770-4754-86bd-22ad65831b62-Britta_Roach.JPG?width=600&height=840&fit=crop&format=pjpg&auto=webp 2x" decoding=async alt="Britta Roach"/><div class="gnt_em_img_ccw gnt_em_img_ccw__cap gnt_em_img_ccw__crd" data-c-caption="Britta Roach" data-c-credit=Submitted></div></figure><p class=gnt_ar_b_p>While this was reassuring, I remain outraged by the mere proposal of the bill and others like it. These bills send a clear, harmful message to trans youth that they are not welcome in society, further perpetuating feelings of isolation and rejection. </p><p class=gnt_ar_b_p>In addition to endangering trans youth, this bill also threatens physicians who provide gender affirming care. Physicians are ethically obligated to treat all patients, without regard to race, religion, gender identity and politics.</p><p class=gnt_ar_b_p>To prohibit gender affirming care would force physicians to make a choice. Either they break the law, or their oath to “first, do no harm”— since to deny gender affirming care would be to deny life saving treatment.</p><aside class="gnt_em gnt_em_hf" data-g-r=lazy data-gl-type=method data-gl-method=loadHb64 aria-label="STATEWIDE SUBSCRIPTION EMBED" data-t-cel=hb64 data-gl-hb64=""></aside><p class=gnt_ar_b_p>As a pediatrician and member of the LGBTQ community, I would choose to do no harm.  </p><p class=gnt_ar_b_p>According to the <a href="https://www.thetrevorproject.org/survey-2021/?section=Introduction" target=_blank rel=noopener data-t-l=":b|e|inline click|${u}" class=gnt_ar_b_a>2021 Trevor Project National Survey</a>, 94% of trans youth reported that recent politics had negatively impacted their mental health; whereas, the use of proper pronouns reduced rates of attempted suicide.</p><p class=gnt_ar_b_p>I wonder if the boy in the ED would have attempted suicide if he had felt supported by his mom, school, and politicians. To those proposing and supporting these bills, I urge you to set aside political plans and personal prejudices.</p><aside aria-label=advertisement class="gnt_m gnt_x gnt_x__lbl gnt_x__al"><div data-g-r=lazy data-gl-method=lazyLoadX id=~ad-slot-7103-tn-nashville-C1056-native-article_link-news-opinion-3 class="gnt_x_sl gnt_x_al"></div></aside><p class=gnt_ar_b_p>Let’s treat children as individual humans rather than policy statements.  </p><p class=gnt_ar_b_p><em>Dr. Britta Roach grew up in White House, Tennessee. She is a pediatrician, and currently a pediatric emergency medicine fellow at Monroe Carell Jr. Children’s Hospital at Vanderbilt in Nashville. This piece reflects the opinion of the author; it does not reflect the opinion of her affiliated institutions.  </em></p></div><div class=gnt_ss data-g-r=base_sc readabilityObject.title: Anti-trans bills in Tennessee have created a mental health crisis | Opinion
readabilityObject.content:
Dr. Britta Roach

  • Dr. Britta Roach is a pediatrician, and currently a pediatric emergency medicine fellow at Monroe Carell Jr. Children’s Hospital at Vanderbilt in Nashville, TN.

As I stepped into the patient’s room, I saw a teenager sitting on the hospital bed. I introduced myself as the physician and asked, “What is your preferred name?” The patient responded with a name different than the one in the medical record and preemptively shared his preferred pronouns: he, him, and his.

As we began talking, he disclosed that he had attempted suicide at home. His mother interrupted, “I found empty pill bottles in her bedroom.” As is typical of all psychiatric assessments, I asked the mother to leave the room so that I could speak to the patient alone.

He opened up more about his transgender identity — sharing that he had attempted suicide due to his unsupportive family and bullying at school. Unfortunately, as a pediatric ED physician, this is a common patient encounter for two reasons.

Suicide is the second leading cause of death among youth, and second, more than half of transgender youth considered suicide in 2021. Despite this disheartening data, legislators across the United States continue to introduce anti-trans bills.

Hear more Tennessee Voices: Get the weekly opinion newsletter for insightful and thought provoking columns.

States across the country are introducing harmful laws

Texas introduced a directive that would re-classify medical treatment for trans youth as child abuse. The Florida Senate passed the “Don’t Say Gay” bill which bans classroom discussion about gender identity.

The Tennessee Senate has proposed the “Youth Health Protection Act,” which would prohibit and criminalize gender affirming medications and surgeries for transgender youth. 

The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP), a professional association of pediatricians, has firmly supported transgender medicine. A policy statement released in 2018, outlining the Gender-Affirmative Care Model whereby “pediatric providers [should] offer developmentally appropriate care that is oriented toward understanding and appreciating the youth’s gender experience.”

Hear from Tennessee's Black Voices: Get the weekly newsletter for powerful and critical thinking columns.

Anti-trans bills negatively affect trans youth's mental health

This month, the Tennessee AAP chapter organized its annual "Day on the Hill," allowing pediatricians to advocate to legislators on behalf of children state-wide. After spending the day expressing our staunch opposition to the “Youth Health Protection Act,” my fellow pediatricians and I learned that this bill would likely not pass.

While this was reassuring, I remain outraged by the mere proposal of the bill and others like it. These bills send a clear, harmful message to trans youth that they are not welcome in society, further perpetuating feelings of isolation and rejection. 

In addition to endangering trans youth, this bill also threatens physicians who provide gender affirming care. Physicians are ethically obligated to treat all patients, without regard to race, religion, gender identity and politics.

To prohibit gender affirming care would force physicians to make a choice. Either they break the law, or their oath to “first, do no harm”— since to deny gender affirming care would be to deny life saving treatment.

As a pediatrician and member of the LGBTQ community, I would choose to do no harm.  

According to the 2021 Trevor Project National Survey, 94% of trans youth reported that recent politics had negatively impacted their mental health; whereas, the use of proper pronouns reduced rates of attempted suicide.

I wonder if the boy in the ED would have attempted suicide if he had felt supported by his mom, school, and politicians. To those proposing and supporting these bills, I urge you to set aside political plans and personal prejudices.

Let’s treat children as individual humans rather than policy statements.  

Dr. Britta Roach grew up in White House, Tennessee. She is a pediatrician, and currently a pediatric emergency medicine fellow at Monroe Carell Jr. Children’s Hospital at Vanderbilt in Nashville. This piece reflects the opinion of the author; it does not reflect the opinion of her affiliated institutions.
